description: From French diplomatique, equal to diplomat +â€Ž -ic.

adjectives.description: diplomatic (comparative more diplomatic, superlative most diplomatic)

entries.meaning: Concerning the relationships between the governments of countries.
examples: She spent thirty years working for Canada's diplomatic service.
Albania immediately severed diplomatic relations with Zimbabwe.

entries.meaning: Exhibiting diplomacy; exercising tact or courtesy; using discussion to avoid hard feelings, fights or arguments.
examples: Thoughtful corrections can be diplomatic as well as instructional.

entries.meaning: Describing a publication of a text which follows a single basic manuscript, but with variants in other manuscripts noted in the critical apparatus.
Relating to diplomatics, or the study of old texts; paleographic.
The science of diplomas, or the art of deciphering ancient writings and determining their age, authenticity, etc.; paleography.
examples: In its broadest aspect, the subject-matter of diplomatic is the relation between documents and facts.
